column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Indio Mariano
#Text=Indio Mariano was an Indigenous rebel against Spain in 1801 in Tepic , Nueva Galicia , now in the Mexican state of Nayarit .
#Text=The background
#Text=With the arrival of the Bourbons on the throne of Spain in 1701 came a period of Indio Mariano , one of them serious , led by different men .
#Text=The first of these took place in Tepic , Nueva Galicia in January .
#Text=The second occurred in September in Nuevo León .
#Text=The first rebellion
#Text=Juan Hilario Rubio , an important man of Tepic , Alcalde José Desiderio Maldonado , and the Indigenous clerk Juan Francisco Medina were the leaders of the first Indio Mariano rebellion .
#Text=These men circulated a proclamation for the crowning of a native of Tlaxcala as Rey de Indias Mariano Primero ( Mariano I , king of the Indies ) .
#Text=This was scheduled for January 6 , 1801 .
#Text=Even before that date , some pueblos were in open rebellion against the Spanish .
#Text=The coronation , however , was frustrated .
#Text=The Spanish officials were able to assemble a force of 762 men and 8 pieces of artillery , relying largely on the local militia and the fleet in the harbor at San Blas .
#Text=For the place and time , this was an overwhelming force .
#Text=The three leaders and many other persons were taken prisoner .
#Text=Many prisoners were taken in two " battles " , one on January 5 and one that day or shortly thereafter .
#Text=The Indigenous offered little resistance and casualties were minimal .
#Text=The rebellion seemed to be over by January 8 , but the following week a second wave appeared .
#Text=The Spanish forces suffered setbacks .
#Text=Large groups of armed Indians were seen in many places , converging on Tepic .
#Text=The Spanish were forced to withdraw from various villages .
#Text=They too converged on Tepic .
#Text=Alarming rumors began to circulate — that 5,000 Yaquis were approaching ; that 6,000 to 7,000 Yumas were coming from the Colorado River .
#Text=The rebellion and the rumors greatly alarmed viceregal officials in Mexico City , particularly since the mother country , and therefore also the colony , was at war with Great Britain .
#Text=They began to fear the possibility of a general Indian uprising , perhaps simultaneously with a British invasion .
#Text=The fears were relieved the following week .
#Text=Reports came in contradicting the rumors of massive movements of warriors .
#Text=Other reports arrived telling of Indians returning peacefully to their villages .
#Text=On January 19 , Captain Leonardo Pintado dispersed a group of armed rebels , taking 33 prisoners .
#Text=The emergency came to an end .
#Text=The Spanish had taken approximately 300 prisoners .
#Text=Most of those arrested were sent to Guadalajara .
#Text=However , some died in jail in Tepic of an unknown disease , some on the march to Guadalajara , and some after arriving in Guadalajara .
#Text=Some of the Spanish troops also suffered from the disease , and some of them died .
#Text=Juan Hilario Rubio was one of the rebels who died in Guadalajara .
#Text=He was condemned postmortem to confiscation of his property , demolition of his house , and sowing of his fields with salt .
#Text=The two other leaders were condemned to six years of public labor in Veracruz .
#Text=This was a sentence that often proved fatal .
#Text=Most of the other surviving prisoners were released .
#Text=Indio Mariano ( also known as Máscara de Oro , or Golden Mask ) was never crowned .
#Text=He was apparently a young Indian itinerant beggar who showed up in Tepic shortly before Christmas 1800 in the company of an old mulatto and a child .
#Text=He claimed to be the son of a deceased governor of Tlaxcala , and to have grown up in luxury .
#Text=It may not have been true that Indio Mariano was a native of Tlaxcala in a literal sense .

#Text=For the Indian resistance of the time , claiming a relationship to Tlaxcala was asserting a claim to the special rights granted the Indigenous of that place by Hernán Cortés at the time of the Conquest .
#Text=Indio Mariano was never found .

#Text=However , rights and titles claimed in connection with Tlaxcalla persisted up until the time of the first Mexican Empire and may have even played a significant role in motivating some natives to side with the conservative forces during the French Intervention .

#Text=There has been speculation that the " Promise of Tlaxcalla " may have played a part in the Cristero Rebellion , due in part to the belief that the catholic rebels were awaiting pontifical approval before crowning an official " Prince of Tlaxcalla " as heir to a " Kingdom of the Aztecs " in fulfillment of the Tlaxcalla Compact .

column1: #Text=One has to believe that the Tlaxcalla Compact may have given rise to the chicano legend of the return of the Quetzalcuatl to unify a broken Aztlan .

#Text=Quetzalcuatl is the chief deity of the allied Aztec tribes who unified themselves under Tlaxcalla and the Spanish , when they liberated Cholula from Mexican control , leading up to the conquest of Tenochtitlan .
#Text=The second " rebellion "
#Text=On September 1 , 1801 in Nuevo León , an Indian by the name of Juan José García was apprehended stealing cattle .
#Text=He told the authorities he was Mariano I or Alejandro I. These were names of kings .
#Text=Mariano asserted that his royal birth and ancestry were documented by papal certificates that he had personally obtained in Rome .
#Text=His case was transferred to the royal medical tribunal , where he was diagnosed as mentally ill with melancholia .
#Text=He was ordered to the hospital of San Hipólito for treatment .
